questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He feels well. He has no urinary urgency, increased urinary frequency, dysuria, or gross hematuria. He has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. His last urinary tract infection was 3 months ago and was treated with ciprofloxacin. Current medications include a multivitamin. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 18 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9500/mm3



Platelet count
170,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

136 mEq/L


K+

4.9 mEq/L


Cl-

101 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
18 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.6 mg/dL


Urine



Blood
2+


Protein
negative


RBC
30–35/hpf, normal shape and size


RBC casts
negative


WBC
0–2/hpf


Bacteria
negative


Urine cultures are negative. Urinalysis is repeated and shows similar results. A cystoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Annual urinalysis is indicated for patients with hematuria and negative workup. While this patient's laboratory tests are negative, his workup has not been completed yet as he requires further testing to rule out anatomic abnormalities (e.g., malignancy).

B) INCORRECT:

Transrectal ultrasound could be utilized in patients with hematuria thought to be caused by benign prostatic hyperplasia or prostate cancer. It may be indicated later in this patients workup, but it is not part of the initial evaluation of hematuria.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is useful to assess for kidney abnormalities or masses in the renal pelvis and upper ureter, and is frequently used to diagnose obstructive uropathy. Ultrasound is recommended for upper urinary tract imaging in patients with an intermediate risk of malignancy, as the incidence of upper urinary tract malignancy in these patients is low. This patient's smoking history of ≥ 30 pack-years and the presence of > 25 RBCs/hpf on urine microscopy indicate that he is at high risk of malignancy. Therefore, a test with a higher sensitivity for detecting upper urinary tract malignancy is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Voided urine cytology can be used in patients with gross hematuria or microscopic hematuria with a negative initial diagnostic workup. However, this test has low sensitivity (i.e. high false-negative rates) and should therefore not be routinely used in the initial evaluation of patients with microhematuria. This patient has not completed the entire initial workup, so urine cytology would not be appropriate at this point.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is indicated if a benign cause of hematuria is suspected (e.g., mild trauma). This patient's initial workup rules out multiple common causes of hematuria (e.g., UTI), but his history of tobacco use, recurrent UTI, and age > 40 are risk factors for urothelial carcinoma, which does require further investigation.

F) CORRECT:

Patients with hematuria should generally be evaluated for UTIs (urinalysis, urine culture), kidney function abnormalities (creatinine, BUN), and glomerular disease (urine microscopy). Other common sources of hematuria (e.g., recent urological procedure or trauma, menstruation in women) also have to be ruled out. To find the source of hematuria (e.g., malignancy), diagnostic evaluation of the entire urinary tract is indicated in all patients with gross hematuria and patients with asymptomatic microhematuria who are at increased risk of malignancy. The testing strategy is based on the risk stratification for microhematuria. Testing consists of cystoscopy to evaluate the lower urinary tract combined with either renal ultrasound (for patients at intermediate risk) or CT urography (for patients at high risk) to evaluate the upper urinary tract. This patient's smoking history of ≥ 30 pack-years and the presence of > 25 RBCs/hpf on urine microscopy indicate that he is at high risk of malignancy.

In CT urography, noncontrast, post-IV contrast, and delayed/excretory phase (> 15 minutes) scans of the abdomen and pelvis (triphasic scan) are obtained to identify the cause of the hematuria. Urothelial carcinomas can be seen as filling defects in the excretory phase.
questions.hint: This patient with asymptomatic microhematuria has strong risk factors for urothelial carcinoma such as tobacco use and chronic urinary tract infections (UTIs).

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of several episodes of dark urine over the past 2 weeks. He does not have dysuria or flank pain. He works in a factory that produces dyes. Since an accident at work 5 years ago, he has had moderate hearing loss bilaterally. He takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 29 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His urine is pink; urinalysis shows 80 RBC/hpf but no WBCs. Cystoscopy shows a 3-cm mass in the bladder mucosa. The mass is resected. Pathologic examination shows a urothelial carcinoma with penetration into the muscular layer. An x-ray of the chest and a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast show a normal upper urinary tract and normal lymph nodes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Transurethral resection of tumor with intravesical chemotherapy
Transurethral resection of tumor with intravesical BCG instillation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) with immediate intravesical chemotherapy (e.g., mitomycin or gemcitabine instillation) can reduce progression and the risk of recurrence in cases of low-grade nonmuscle-invasive bladder cancer. However, this patient's urothelial cancer has already invaded the muscular layer of the bladder, which requires a different approach.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy with or without concurrent chemotherapy can be considered in patients with muscle-invasive bladder cancers. However, radiation therapy is typically reserved for patients who are not suitable candidates for first-line treatment, which this patient has not received yet and has no contraindication to.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravesical BCG instillation after transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) reduces the progression and risk of recurrence in patients with high-grade nonmuscle invasive bladder cancer. However, this patient's urothelial cancer has already invaded the muscular layer of the bladder, which requires a different approach.

D) CORRECT:

How bladder cancer is managed depends mainly on its stage. In patients with muscle-invasive bladder cancer without positive lymph nodes or distant metastasis, radical cystectomy with the construction of a urinary diversion (e.g., neobladder or ileal conduit) is the treatment of choice if the patient is a suitable surgical candidate and is willing to undergo the procedure. Neoadjuvant cisplatin-based chemotherapy should generally be offered, as it is associated with a survival benefit. However, this patient's hearing loss is a contraindication to cisplatin, as the drug is associated with considerable ototoxicity and adjuvant chemotherapy should be considered.

This patient's tumor is a urothelial cell carcinoma (transitional cell carcinoma), which is the most common type of bladder cancer in the United States and Europe. In areas of the world where Schistosoma haematobium is endemic (particularly the Middle East and Africa), squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of bladder carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Palliative polychemotherapy is used in patients with advanced metastatic bladder cancer. In addition to symptom control, it may also provide a modest survival advantage. However, this patient's cancer has not metastasized (no abnormalities on chest x-ray and normal abdominal and pelvic CT scans). A different course of management is therefore required.
questions.hint: This patient has muscle-invasive urothelial cancer without metastasis. His smoking history and occupational exposure to dye are important risk factors that have likely played a role in the development of his bladder cancer.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of painless hematuria. A CT scan of the urinary tract shows areas of bladder wall thickening. Cystoscopy shows several sessile masses with central necrosis arising from the bladder wall. A biopsy specimen of the bladder masses shows moderately differentiated urothelial cells with abundant mitotic figures and nuclear atypia. The patient most likely has a history of exposure to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exposure to ionizing radiation is associated with certain occupations, previous cancer treatments, and living environments (e.g., near nuclear power plants). It has been found to be associated with later development of papillary thyroid cancer, not bladder cancer.

B) CORRECT:

A strong risk factor for urothelial cancer is prolonged exposure to aromatic amines like benzidine. These chemicals are especially associated with the rubber production, oil refining, and dye-making industries. Other risk factors for urothelial cancer include nicotine abuse, arsenic exposure, and cyclophosphamide use.

C) INCORRECT:

Nitrosamines are compounds formed from nitrites and amines and are found in certain foods like smoked meats. They have been found to be carcinogenic, but are most closely associated with the development of gastric cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Aflatoxins are toxins produced by Aspergillus flavus, which is a fungus that can grow on improperly stored nuts and rice. Although aflatoxins are carcinogenic, they have been primarily linked to hepatocellular carcinoma and not urothelial cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Vinyl chloride is a chemical that especially plumbers are exposed to when working with polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes. Although vinyl chloride is carcinogenic, it has primarily been linked to liver angiosarcoma and not urothelial cancer. It also increases the risk of brain cancer, lung cancer, leukemia, and lymphoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Radon is a radioactive gas that forms as a byproduct from decay of uranium, thorium, and radium. Its concentration can be high in mines and poorly ventilated basements. Although it is the second leading cause of lung cancer, it is not associated with urothelial cancer.
questions.hint: A history of painless hematuria, combined with the cystoscopic finding of bladder masses composed of atypical urothelial cells, is consistent with urothelial carcinoma.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of urinary frequency, dysuria, and blood in his urine. He has also had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months and has been feeling more fatigued than usual. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 2 years ago. A urinalysis shows 3+ blood. Cystoscopy shows an irregular mass on the bladder wall; a biopsy is taken. Which of the following histologic findings would indicate the worst survival prognosis?

choices.text: Dysplastic cells extending into the lamina propria
Nests of atypical cells in the urothelium
Disordered urothelium lined with papillary fronds

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Dysplastic cells extending into the lamina propria indicate an invasive tumor (T1 stage), which carries a worse prognosis than a tumor that does not invade the lamina propria (Tis or tumor in situ). Bladder cancer is most common in men > 65 years and in those who have a history of nicotine abuse or exposure to carcinogens (e.g., aniline dye, azo dye, heavy metals). It usually presents with gross hematuria with irritative voiding symptoms, both of which are seen in this patient. Invasive tumors must be resected.

B) INCORRECT:

Nests of atypical cells in the urothelium indicate that the cancer is localized on (or near) the bladder surface. This finding is consistent with carcinoma in situ (stage: Tis or tumor in situ). Such tumors are most frequently low-grade intraepithelial neoplasias and have a more promising prognosis compared to those with the other listed histological changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Friable urothelium with ulcerations is a nonspecific finding that is frequently observed as a urothelial reactive change (reactive atypia) in a chronic inflammatory setting such as chronic cystitis. Regardless of the specific etiology, these cytologic and architectural abnormalities generally represent a benign process, which does not have a significant effect on survival.

D) INCORRECT:

Disordered urothelium lined with papillary fronds indicates a superficial neoplasm that has not spread to deeper layers (stage: Ta). Non-invasive papillary carcinoma has a high risk of recurrence but the recurrent tumors are most often of similar stage and grade. A different histological change would carry a worse survival prognosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Tubular glands with mucin secretions indicate glandular differentiation, which is a feature of adenocarcinoma, a rare bladder tumor. These neoplasms are typically already at an advanced stage (e.g., with pelvic node involvement) on presentation. When comparing patients with adenocarcinomas and urothelial carcinomas of the same stage, the survival rates are similar. Adenocarcinoma itself is not a poor prognostic factor.
questions.hint: Hematuria, dysuria, polyuria, and weight loss in a patient with significant tobacco use history should raise concern for bladder cancer. In patients with bladder cancer, tumor staging is the most important factor in determining prognosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of several episodes of dark urine over the past 2 months. He has had a 6 kg (13.2-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months despite no changes in appetite. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. A CT scan shows a heterogeneous enhancing mass arising from the left renal pelvis. Pathologic examination of the lesion is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Pedunculated tumor comprised of pleomorphic urothelial cells with severe nuclear atypia
Grayish-brown tumor comprised of squamous cells with keratin pearls
Tumor with central scar comprised of large eosinophilic cells with central nuclei
Bright yellow tumor comprised of polygonal cells filled with lipids and glycogen
Grayish-tan tumor comprised of primitive blastemal cells forming abortive glomeruli

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

More than 90% of tumors arising from the renal pelvis and ureter are urothelial carcinomas. They typically manifest with either gross or microscopic hematuria (75% of cases), while flank pain only sometimes occurs (20% of cases). Less often, a lumbar mass or recurrent urinary tract infections are seen. The urinary collecting system is derived from the same embryologic origin (the ureteric bud), and, as a result, urothelial carcinomas appear identical to tumors arising from the bladder, with a papillary surface, large pleomorphic urothelial cells, and severe nuclear atypia. Tumors are often pedunculated.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of urothelial tissue (H&E stain; 750x magnification)

Papillary urothelial carcinoma with lamina propria infiltration, moderately differentiated.

A) Mitotic figure
B) Urothelial cell with severe nuclear atypia; no mitotic figure
C) Small, round lymphocytes; no mitotic figure
D) Structure with a nucleus
E) Atypical urothelial cell; no mitotic figure

B) INCORRECT:

Primary squamous cell cancer (SCC) of the renal pelvis accounts for less than 10% of all renal pelvic cancers. They are sometimes seen in association with chronic calculi or chronic infections. SCC is an aggressive tumor, often locally invasive at the time of diagnosis. Unlike the tumor in this patient, they tend to be sessile and not pedunculated. When present, they appear as grayish-brown tumors comprised of squamous cells with keratin pearls.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal oncocytomas are benign tumors that arise from the collecting ducts, not from the renal pelvis. They are usually incidental findings and are rarely symptomatic, unless they grow to be very large in size, at which point they can manifest with hematuria and/or flank pain, neither of which is present here. Pathologic examination of the tumor would reveal a central scar comprised of large eosinophilic cells with central nuclei and numerous mitochondria, without dysplastic urothelial cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinomas are bright yellow tumors comprised of polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and glycogen. They arise from the renal parenchyma, more specifically from the proximal convoluted tubule. Tumors of the renal pelvis are of urothelial origin.

E) INCORRECT:

Nephroblastoma, the most common renal tumor in children, has a grayish-tan appearance and is comprised of primitive blastemal cells that form abortive glomeruli. It usually manifests as a large abdominal mass and is sometimes associated with hematuria and abdominal pain, neither of which is the case here. Moreover, it is not seen in adults, making it extremely unlikely in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's renal pelvic mass has arisen from cells that derive from the caudal end of the mesonephric duct during embryologic development.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of urinary frequency and urgency for 2 weeks. He is especially concerned because last week he also noticed blood in his urine for the first time. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 44 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a nondistended, nontender abdomen; there is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Digital rectal examination shows a mildly enlarged, nontender prostate without palpable masses. Urinalysis shows 50 RBCs/hpf. A cystoscopy shows a 2-cm tumor on the posterior wall of the bladder; biopsy shows a urothelial carcinoma in situ. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a normal thickness bladder wall with no evidence of extravesical extension or nodal involvement. The most appropriate next step in management should include which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Partial cystectomy can be used to treat small, solitary, muscle-invasive UBC with a specific location (e.g., posterior bladder wall, bladder dome) and certain rare forms of bladder cancers (e.g., urachal adenocarcinoma). This patient has nonmuscle invasive UBC, which requires a different treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Radical cystectomy is used to treat muscle-invasive UBC. However, this patient has nonmuscle invasive UBC, for which radical cystectomy is not a first-line treatment and is only considered if the initial treatment is unsuccessful.

C) INCORRECT:

External beam radiation therapy is an acceptable first-line treatment option for localized prostate cancer and for certain rare forms of bladder cancer (e.g., squamous cell cancer due to schistosomiasis). However, radiation therapy is not used as a first-line treatment for nonmuscle invasive UBC. It is generally reserved for palliative care or as part of a multimodal bladder-sparing approach in patients with muscle-invasive UBC.

D) CORRECT:

Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) is the best initial treatment for nonmuscle invasive UBC. During the procedure, an electrocautery-resectoscope is used to remove all visible neoplastic tissue up to the muscular layer of the bladder. Because of the possibility of multifocal CIS, areas of bladder mucosa that appear normal should also be biopsied during TURBT. To minimize the high risk of recurrence of urothelial CIS (due to tumor cell reimplantation), following TURBT, adjuvant intravesical instillation of antineoplastic drugs (e.g., mitomycin) or Bacillus Calmette-Guérin is often performed (especially for high-grade tumors). Patients should subsequently undergo periodic surveillance using cystoscopy and urine cytology.

Neoadjuvant systemic chemotherapy (with a cisplatin-based regimen) followed by radical cystectomy is the treatment of choice for patients with muscle-invasive UBC who are candidates for curative surgery (stage II or III disease) and willing to undergo the subsequent urinary diversion procedure. For patients who are unwilling to undergo cystectomy, a multimodal bladder-sparing approach (with TURBT and concurrent chemoradiotherapy) is performed. Patients with stage IV UBC receive chemotherapy and, depending on the tumor burden, palliative care with TURBT and/or radiotherapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic chemotherapy is a possible treatment for patients with muscle-invasive UBC. This patient has nonmuscle invasive UBC, which is treated with local (intravesical) rather than systemic chemotherapy.
questions.hint: The treatment of choice for nonmuscle invasive urothelial bladder cancer (UBC), such as this patient's urothelial carcinoma in situ (CIS), is performed in a similar manner to treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-day history of intermittent red urine. He has not had flank pain, fever, dysuria, or increased urinary frequency. He has no history of recent trauma. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and atrial fibrillation. His medications include lisinopril and warfarin. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 137/64 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Digital rectal examination shows a smooth, normal-sized prostate without any irregularities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.0 g/dL


Prothrombin time
48 sec (INR = 4)


Serum



Creatinine
1 mg/dL


Urine



Blood
3+


Protein
negative


RBC
too numerous to count


WBC
2/hpf


Casts
none


Nitrites
negative


Leukocyte esterase
negative


In addition to adjusting the patient's warfarin dosage, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the kidneys and bladder

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While this patient's increased INR puts him at risk for warfarin-associated urinary tract bleeding, repeating the urinalysis one week after adjusting the warfarin dosage is not the most appropriate next step at this point. All patients with unexplained gross hematuria should undergo further diagnostic evaluation of the urinary tract for underlying malignancy irrespective of anticoagulation therapy.

This question is designed to test your knowledge of the diagnostic workup of gross hematuria. The vignettes in your exam may sometimes contain confounding information, which can cause you to deviate from the standard process of diagnosing or managing a condition. In this case, the patient's increased INR puts him at risk for warfarin-associated urinary tract bleeding. However, it is not yet clear that the patient's gross hematuria is associated with increased INR. All patients with unexplained gross hematuria should undergo further evaluation of the urinary tract for underlying malignancy, regardless of anticoagulation therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Urine cultures are performed to rule out urinary tract infection (UTI), which can manifest with gross hematuria. However, this patient has no other clinical signs of UTI (e.g., dysuria, increased urinary frequency) and his urine dipstick is negative for white blood cells, nitrite, and leukocyte esterase. Therefore, it is not necessary to perform a urine culture.

C) INCORRECT:

This question is designed to test your knowledge of the diagnostic workup of patients with gross hematuria. Identifying the next step in management requires you to consider the different etiologies of gross hematuria in a specific patient population (e.g., older men with urinary tract cancer) and then determine which diagnostic tests are indicated to evaluate these conditions. Ultrasound of the kidneys and bladder can be performed to evaluate the upper urinary tract and bladder for a tumor, but this test is only used as an initial imaging examination in pregnant patients with hematuria. Instead, CT urography is preferred for imaging of the urinary tract, as it is more specific and sensitive for urinary tract malignancies than ultrasound.

D) INCORRECT:

Retrograde pyelography can be performed to rule out upper urinary tract malignancies, which can manifest with gross hematuria. However, this examination is typically used as an alternative for patients who have contraindications to CT urography (e.g., iodine allergy), which this patient does not have. Moreover, neither retrograde pyelography nor CT urography can provide a complete evaluation of the urinary system; both need to be combined with another diagnostic test.

E) CORRECT:

Cystoscopy is indicated in any patient with gross hematuria that is not explained by UTI (i.e., negative nitrites and leukocyte esterase on urine dipstick) or glomerular disease (i.e., no proteinuria). This procedure enables direct visualization of the urethral and bladder mucosa with possible biopsy collection and can reliably detect malignancy or other sources of bleeding. Cystoscopy should be combined with CT urography for evaluation of the entire urinary tract.

Cystoscopy is also indicated in men ≥ 40 years of age and women ≥ 50 years of age with microhematuria as well as in younger patients with microhematuria who have risk factors for urinary tract malignancy (e.g., tobacco use, cyclophosphamide treatment, prolonged exposure to aniline dye).
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the bladder

A lateral bladder wall lesion is visible during bipolar transurethral resection.
questions.hint: Painless gross hematuria is the most common manifestation of bladder cancer, so this patient requires a thorough diagnostic evaluation irrespective of his supratherapeutic INR.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man with no comorbidities is evaluated for hematuria. He is thin, has never smoked, and has no family or personal history of genitourinary or other cancers. He reports no exposure to pelvic irradiation, does not have a history of a bladder defect at birth, and has no history of recurrent bladder infections or stones.
Urine cytology reveals abnormal cells with a very high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, dark coarse chromatin, and irregular borders; prominent nucleoli are occasionally seen in large, often single cells.
What is the most appropriate question to ask this patient to complete his history regarding potential risk factors for bladder cancer?

choices.text: Have you traveled to North Africa or the Middle East?
How many sexual partners have you had in your lifetime?
Have you had extensive exposure to commercial dyes?
Can you tell me about your alcohol consumption?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Travel to or previous residence in North Africa or the Middle East may expose people to an infection with schistosomiasis, but this is linked to squamous-cell bladder cancer rather than urothelial cancer. The urine cytology findings differ between these two types of bladder cancer. In squamous-cell carcinomas, the urine cytology typically reveals abnormal cells with abundant, dense cytoplasm that can be intensely eosinophilic; nuclei are large and hyperchromatic with irregular nuclear borders. In urothelial cancer, urine cytology shows abnormal cells with a very high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, dark coarse chromatin, and irregular borders; prominent nucleoli are occasionally seen in large, often single cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Although sexual history can be useful to evaluate risks for cancers related to HIV, hepatitis C virus, and human papillomavirus, bladder cancer is not clearly associated with sexually transmitted infections.

C) CORRECT:

Ninety percent of bladder cancers are urothelial carcinomas, and 10% are squamous-cell carcinomas. In this case, the urine cytology indicates a urothelial carcinoma.

Occupational exposures are a major risk factor for bladder cancer, and certain chemicals used in the dye, chemical, and rubber industries (aromatic amines, such as benzidine and beta-naphthylamine) have been associated specifically with urothelial carcinoma. Other known risk factors for bladder cancer include tobacco use, chronic bladder irritation and infections, bladder birth defects, personal history of bladder or urothelial cancer, prior chronic cyclophosphamide chemotherapy or pelvic radiation therapy, and exposure to arsenic.

Key learning point: The type of bladder cancer whose risk is associated with exposure to aromatic amine dyes is urothelial carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Bladder cancer is not associated with heavy alcohol use.

E) INCORRECT:

Bladder cancer is not associated with tattoos.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman who is otherwise well reports a 2-day history of hematuria. She underwent menopause 13 years ago.
Her father was diagnosed with colorectal cancer at age 49, and her grandfather died from colon cancer in his sixth decade. She has three sisters, one with a history of ovarian cancer and another with a history of endometrial cancer.
Results of a complete blood count, coagulation studies, and kidney function tests are all within normal limits. Urinalysis shows >100 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2). No casts or dysmorphic red cells are noted.
What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hematuria may be caused by abnormalities in the urologic tract from the glomeruli to the urethra, and evaluation should include a detailed history to help prioritize the evaluation.

In this case, the family history of cancer is of great concern, because it is highly suggestive of Lynch syndrome, a familial cancer syndrome that is characterized by an increased risk for cancer of the upper urologic tract, as well as cancers of the colon, endometrium, ovaries, small bowel, bile duct, pancreas, skin, and brain. Lynch syndrome is diagnosed on the basis of the Amsterdam II criteria (≥3 affected members in the family, involving ≥2 generations in which ≥1 cancer is diagnosed before age 50).

Although evaluation of microscopic hematuria is guided by the patient’s risk for urothelial carcinoma, evaluation of persistent gross hematuria (in the absence of features to suggest intrinsic renal disease such as dysmorphic erythrocytes, elevated creatinine levels, or significant proteinuria) should always include imaging of both the upper urinary tract (with CT urography) and the lower urinary tract (with cystoscopy). CT urography should generally precede cystoscopy — and is especially important to prioritize in a patient with concern for Lynch syndrome, which specifically increases the risk for upper urinary tract cancers. If any upper urinary tract findings are noted on CT urography, they will be endoscopically evaluated (and potentially biopsied) in the operating room; during this evaluation, the lower urinary tract can also be visualized, sparing the patient a redundant office cystoscopy procedure.

Key learning point: All patients presenting with gross hematuria should be evaluated with CT urography (followed by cystoscopy) to rule out malignancy; this is particularly important for patients with Lynch syndrome who are at increased risk for urothelial carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is less sensitive than CT at detecting small, solid lesions and is therefore typically not a recommended imaging modality for the upper urinary tract in high-risk patients such as this one.

C) INCORRECT:

Although evaluation of microscopic hematuria is guided by the patient’s risk for urothelial carcinoma, evaluation of persistent gross hematuria (in the absence of features to suggest intrinsic renal disease such as dysmorphic erythrocytes, elevated creatinine levels, or significant proteinuria) should always include imaging of both the upper urinary tract (with CT urography) and the lower urinary tract (with cystoscopy). CT urography should generally precede cystoscopy — and is especially important to prioritize in a patient with concern for Lynch syndrome, which specifically increases the risk for upper urinary tract cancers. If any upper urinary tract findings are noted on CT urography, they will be endoscopically evaluated (and potentially biopsied) in the operating room; during this evaluation, the lower urinary tract can also be visualized, sparing the patient a redundant office cystoscopy procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology is not sufficiently sensitive and is therefore not recommended as part of the algorithm for evaluating hematuria.

E) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasonography could be considered if the patient had abnormal uterine bleeding.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man is seen for his second episode of painless gross hematuria within the past 10 days. Between episodes, he is asymptomatic, and his urine is odorless and normal in color. He has been otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He smoked cigarettes for 35 years and quit 5 years ago. His physical examination is unremarkable.
His serum creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3). Urinalysis reveals pink urine. Urine microscopy reveals >100 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), with no casts or dysmorphic red cells.
In addition to referral for cystoscopy, which one of the following imaging studies is most appropriate?

choices.text: Radiograph of the abdomen and pelvis
MRI of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A radiograph of the abdomen and pelvis would provide little information; it will not visualize tumors or radiolucent stones.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography is good for detecting medullary sponge kidney and large renal masses and was historically used for the evaluation of hematuria, but it has been replaced by the excretory phase of the CT urogram. Intravenous pyelography has a much lower sensitivity for renal masses smaller than 2 to 3 cm and can miss peripheral lesions.

C) CORRECT:

Hematuria can occur from glomerular diseases or structural abnormalities of the urinary tract, including renal-cell carcinoma, urothelial malignancy, urolithiasis, or papillary necrosis.

All patients who have visible or gross hematuria without a clear cause should undergo evaluation of the upper urinary tract, by imaging and evaluation of the lower urinary tract by cystoscopy, to determine the source of hematuria and exclude malignancy. The evaluation of microscopic nonglomerular hematuria is more complex and is determined, in part, by risk factors such as age, history of smoking, and exposure to potential carcinogens.

The single best imaging study to evaluate the source of hematuria in the upper urinary tract is CT urography. Without contrast, CT urography will identify kidney stones of every type; with contrast, it can detect even small lesions in the cortex of the kidney.

Key learning point: All patients with unexplained gross hematuria should have an evaluation to exclude malignancy that includes cystoscopy and CT urography.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
β-hCG: beta-human chorionic gonadotropin
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
HPF: high-power field
RBC: red blood cell
UA: urinalysis
US: ultrasound
UTI: urinary tract infection

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the abdomen and pelvis is not recommended as a first-line study in this case because its sensitivity and specificity have not been well studied. Nevertheless, it can be used as an aid to further characterize known lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

A retroperitoneal ultrasound to assess kidney size and echogenicity could be appropriate if there were evidence of a glomerular source of hematuria. Ultrasound can detect kidney stones in the renal pelvis and can also distinguish cystic from solid masses, but it can miss small lesions and kidney stones in the ureter. This modality can play a useful role in individuals who cannot tolerate contrast (as in chronic kidney disease) or radiation exposure (as in pregnancy).

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman with a history of cigarette smoking (40 pack-years), mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents for follow-up evaluation 4 weeks after an episode of gross hematuria.
During the initial episode, urinalysis with microscopy revealed >100 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), 20 to 30 white cells per high-power field (0–2), and occasional bacteria. She was given a 3-day course of ciprofloxacin.
Today, the patient reports no further episodes of gross hematuria, and she states she does not experience any dysuria or flank pain. Urinalysis reveals 40 to 50 red cells per high-power field, and urine culture is negative. Her urine protein-to-creatinine ratio is 0.1 mg/mg (reference range, <0.2).
Serum laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.5
12.0–16.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
5000
4500–11,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.8
0.6–1.1


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.2
9.0–10.5


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
12
10–20


In addition to cystoscopy, which one of the following tests is most appropriate for evaluating this patient?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast
CT urography with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nephrology referral for hematuria is reasonable in patients who appear to have a glomerular cause of their hematuria (albuminuria, dysmorphic red cells, red-cell casts, elevated serum creatinine, or new or worsening hypertension or edema) or in patients whose hematuria is unexplained. Such a referral would be premature for this patient at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

CT without contrast would be helpful for diagnosing kidney stones but could miss important lesions in the kidney.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasonography is not the preferred mode of evaluation for patients with normal renal function (as in this case) because it is not sufficiently sensitive to detect neoplasms <3 cm. It is a reasonable alternative, however, for patients with reduced renal function, given that it does not require contrast.

D) INCORRECT:

In young patients with incidental microscopic nonglomerular hematuria and no risk factors for urothelial cancer (e.g., cigarette smoking), a repeat urinalysis may be sufficient. This patient requires further workup.

E) CORRECT:

Even a single episode of painless gross hematuria or asymptomatic microscopic hematuria (defined as ≥3 red cells per high-power field on microscopic analysis) requires further evaluation. Hematuria can originate from a glomerular source or a nonglomerular source. A glomerular source is more likely when there is proteinuria, dysmorphic red cells, or cellular casts. This patient has no features to suggest a glomerular source. Therefore, the patient should be evaluated for causes of bleeding from the upper urinary tract (neoplasm, nephrolithiasis, or cystic disease) or the lower urinary tract (bladder, urethra, or [in men] prostate).

All patients with gross (visible) nonglomerular hematuria without an obvious explanation should undergo an evaluation with cystoscopy and a radiologic evaluation of the upper urinary tract, typically CT urography. Patients without a history of gross hematuria in whom incidental microscopic nonglomerular hematuria is noted should undergo a similar evaluation if risk factors for urothelial cancer are present, such as age ≥50 for women, age ≥40 for men, cigarette smoking, or relevant chemical exposures. In younger, lower-risk patients, a repeat urinalysis in 6 months may be sufficient with further evaluation only if the microscopic hematuria persists.

CT urography with and without contrast is now considered the gold standard in evaluating upper urinary tract causes of hematuria. Imaging done without contrast can detect kidney stones of every variety, whereas imaging done with contrast can detect small parenchymal lesions that could be missed by ultrasound, a CT without contrast, or an intravenous pyelogram.

Urine cytology identifies most high-grade lesions but is not sensitive enough to detect uroepithelial cancer and is therefore not recommended in the evaluation of hematuria. Although treatment for a urinary tract infection at the onset of this patient’s illness was reasonable, the lack of symptoms to support a urinary tract infection makes it an unlikely cause of the hematuria, and a repeat urine culture is unlikely to explain the ongoing hematuria.

Key learning point: All patients with unexplained gross hematuria should have an evaluation to exclude malignancy that includes cystoscopy and CT urography with and without contrast.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
β-hCG: beta-human chorionic gonadotropin
CBC: complete blood count
CT: computed tomography
HPF: high-power field
RBC: red blood cell
UA: urinalysis
US: ultrasound
UTI: urinary tract infection

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man who is a former smoker presents with gross hematuria. He has no prior history of hematuria or genitourinary cancer.
On cystoscopy, a solitary velvety erythematous patch of mucosa, 3.2 cm in diameter, is found in the bladder. Resection and fulguration is performed; no intravesical therapy is administered.
Histologic evaluation confirms high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma of the bladder with invasion of the lamina propria.
No lymphadenopathy, renal parenchymal mass, or filling defects within the renal pelvises or ureters is seen on CT urography.
Which one of the following management options is the most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Repeat cystoscopy with transurethral resection and fulguration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy does not have a role in treating this type of cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Radical cystectomy is considered standard therapy for stage II and stage III bladder cancer (where there is invasion of the muscularis layer). It may also be an option in patients with extensive or refractory stage Ta or stage I cancer. It is not indicated in this case of a first occurrence of stage I bladder cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Partial cystectomy is rarely performed for this indication, given that recurrent tumors tend to occur throughout the bladder.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravesical BCG or chemotherapy instillations are considered standard therapy in most patients with non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer (especially those patients at high risk for progression or with multiple or recurrent tumors) and will help reduce recurrence risk. However, it is not indicated until after repeat cystoscopy has been performed.

E) CORRECT:

This tumor is considered high risk for recurrence and progression based on the high-grade pathologic changes. In a patient with no previous history of genitourinary cancer who undergoes initial transurethral resection of high-risk non-muscle-invasive high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, the most appropriate next step in management is to repeat the cystoscopy within 6 weeks of the initial cystoscopy, with resection of any residual or synchronous tumors. This approach provides both diagnostic and therapeutic benefit.

In patients with bladder cancer that invades the lamina propria but not the muscularis layer (staged as T1 disease), disease understaging is common, with up to 30% of patients being upstaged to muscle-invasive disease at repeat resection. From a therapeutic standpoint, 50% to 70% of patients with T1 tumors may have residual disease at the time of repeat cystoscopy. Repeat resection is associated with improved response to subsequent intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) therapy or mitomycin C therapy.

Key learning point: In a patient with no previous history of genitourinary cancer who undergoes initial transurethral resection of high-risk non-muscle-invasive high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, the most appropriate next step in management is repeat transurethral resection and fulguration.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the office because of urinary frequency and urgency for 2 weeks. He is especially concerned because last week he also noticed blood in his urine for the first time. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 44 years. Physical examination shows a nondistended, nontender abdomen; there is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows 50 RBCs/hpf. A cystoscopy shows a 2-cm tumor on the posterior wall of the bladder; biopsy shows a urothelial carcinoma in situ. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a normal thickness bladder wall with no evidence of extravesical extension or nodal involvement. The most appropriate next step in management should include which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Partial cystectomy can be used to treat small, solitary, muscle-invasive UBC with a specific location (e.g., posterior bladder wall, bladder dome) and certain rare forms of bladder cancers (e.g., urachal adenocarcinoma). This patient has nonmuscle invasive UBC, which requires a different treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Radical cystectomy is used to treat muscle-invasive UBC. However, this patient has nonmuscle invasive UBC, for which radical cystectomy is not a first-line treatment and is only considered if the initial treatment is unsuccessful.

C) INCORRECT:

External beam radiation therapy is an acceptable first-line treatment option for localized prostate cancer and for certain rare forms of bladder cancer (e.g., squamous cell cancer due to schistosomiasis). However, radiation therapy is not used as a first-line treatment for nonmuscle invasive UBC. It is generally reserved for palliative care or as part of a multimodal bladder-sparing approach in patients with muscle-invasive UBC.

D) CORRECT:

Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) is the best initial treatment for nonmuscle invasive UBC. During the procedure, an electrocautery-resectoscope is used to remove all visible neoplastic tissue up to the muscular layer of the bladder. Because of the possibility of multifocal CIS, areas of bladder mucosa that appear normal should also be biopsied during TURBT. To minimize the high risk of recurrence of urothelial CIS (due to tumor cell reimplantation), following TURBT, adjuvant intravesical instillation of antineoplastic drugs (e.g., mitomycin) or Bacillus Calmette-Guérin is often performed (especially for high-grade tumors). Patients should subsequently undergo periodic surveillance using cystoscopy and urine cytology.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic chemotherapy is a possible treatment for patients with muscle-invasive UBC. This patient has nonmuscle invasive UBC, which is treated with local (intravesical) rather than systemic chemotherapy.
questions.hint: The treatment of choice for nonmuscle invasive urothelial bladder cancer (UBC), such as this patient's urothelial carcinoma in situ (CIS), is performed in a similar manner to treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with no comorbidities is evaluated for hematuria. He is thin, has never smoked, and has no family or personal history of genitourinary or other cancers. He reports no exposure to pelvic irradiation, does not have a history of a bladder defect at birth, and has no history of recurrent bladder infections or stones. Urine cytology reveals abnormal cells with a very high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, dark coarse chromatin, and irregular borders; prominent nucleoli are occasionally seen in large, often single cells indicating urothelial carcinoma. What is the most appropriate question to ask this patient to complete his history regarding potential risk factors for bladder cancer?

choices.text: Have you traveled to North Africa or the Middle East?
How many sexual partners have you had in your lifetime?
Have you had extensive exposure to commercial dyes?
Can you tell me about your alcohol consumption?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Travel to or previous residence in North Africa or the Middle East may expose people to an infection with schistosomiasis, but this is linked to squamous-cell bladder cancer rather than urothelial cancer. The urine cytology findings differ between these two types of bladder cancer. In squamous-cell carcinomas, the urine cytology typically reveals abnormal cells with abundant, dense cytoplasm that can be intensely eosinophilic; nuclei are large and hyperchromatic with irregular nuclear borders. In urothelial cancer, urine cytology shows abnormal cells with a very high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, dark coarse chromatin, and irregular borders; prominent nucleoli are occasionally seen in large, often single cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Although sexual history can be useful to evaluate risks for cancers related to HIV, hepatitis C virus, and human papillomavirus, bladder cancer is not clearly associated with sexually transmitted infections.

C) CORRECT:

Ninety percent of bladder cancers are urothelial carcinomas, and 10% are squamous-cell carcinomas. Occupational exposures are a major risk factor for bladder cancer, and certain chemicals used in the dye, chemical, and rubber industries (aromatic amines, such as benzidine and beta-naphthylamine) have been associated specifically with urothelial carcinoma. Other known risk factors for bladder cancer include tobacco use, chronic bladder irritation and infections, bladder birth defects, personal history of bladder or urothelial cancer, prior chronic cyclophosphamide chemotherapy or pelvic radiation therapy, and exposure to arsenic.

Key learning point: The type of bladder cancer whose risk is associated with exposure to aromatic amine dyes is urothelial carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Bladder cancer is not associated with heavy alcohol use.

E) INCORRECT:

Bladder cancer is not associated with tattoos.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the office with a 1-week history of painless hematuria. A CT scan of the urinary tract shows areas of bladder wall thickening. Cystoscopy shows several sessile masses with central necrosis arising from the bladder wall. A biopsy specimen of the bladder masses shows moderately differentiated urothelial cells with abundant mitotic figures and nuclear atypia. The patient most likely has a history of exposure to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exposure to ionizing radiation is associated with certain occupations, previous cancer treatments, and living environments (e.g., near nuclear power plants). It has been found to be associated with later development of papillary thyroid cancer, not bladder cancer.

B) CORRECT:

A strong risk factor for urothelial cancer is prolonged exposure to aromatic amines like benzidine. These chemicals are especially associated with the rubber production, oil refining, and dye-making industries. Other risk factors for urothelial cancer include nicotine abuse, arsenic exposure, and cyclophosphamide use.

C) INCORRECT:

Nitrosamines are compounds formed from nitrites and amines and are found in certain foods like smoked meats. They have been found to be carcinogenic, but are most closely associated with the development of gastric cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Aflatoxins are toxins produced by Aspergillus flavus, which is a fungus that can grow on improperly stored nuts and rice. Although aflatoxins are carcinogenic, they have been primarily linked to hepatocellular carcinoma and not urothelial cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Vinyl chloride is a chemical that especially plumbers are exposed to when working with polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes. Although vinyl chloride is carcinogenic, it has primarily been linked to liver angiosarcoma and not urothelial cancer. It also increases the risk of brain cancer, lung cancer, leukemia, and lymphoma.
questions.hint: A history of painless hematuria, combined with the cystoscopic finding of bladder masses composed of atypical urothelial cells, is consistent with urothelial carcinoma.

questions.text: You are evaluating a 74-year-old man with no comorbidities who presents with hematuria. He is thin, has never smoked, and has no personal or family history of genitourinary or other cancers. He reports no exposure to pelvic irradiation, no history of a bladder defect at birth, and no history of recurrent bladder infections or stones. Urine cytology shows abnormal cells with a very high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, dark coarse chromatin, irregular borders, and occasional prominent nucleoli in large, often single cells, consistent with urothelial carcinoma. Which one of the following is the most appropriate question to ask to complete his history regarding potential risk factors for bladder cancer?

choices.text: Have you had extensive exposure to commercial dyes?.
Have you traveled to North Africa or the Middle East?.
Can you tell me about your alcohol consumption?.
How many sexual partners have you had in your lifetime?.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ninety percent of bladder cancers are urothelial carcinomas, and 10% are squamous-cell carcinomas. Occupational exposures are a major risk factor for bladder cancer, and certain chemicals used in the dye, chemical, and rubber industries (aromatic amines, such as benzidine and beta-naphthylamine) have been associated specifically with urothelial carcinoma. Other known risk factors for bladder cancer include tobacco use, chronic bladder irritation and infections, bladder birth defects, personal history of bladder or urothelial cancer, prior chronic cyclophosphamide chemotherapy or pelvic radiation therapy, and exposure to arsenic.

Key learning point: The type of bladder cancer whose risk is associated with exposure to aromatic amine dyes is urothelial carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Travel to or previous residence in North Africa or the Middle East may expose people to an infection with schistosomiasis, but this is linked to squamous-cell bladder cancer rather than urothelial cancer. The urine cytology findings differ between these two types of bladder cancer. In squamous-cell carcinomas, the urine cytology typically reveals abnormal cells with abundant, dense cytoplasm that can be intensely eosinophilic; nuclei are large and hyperchromatic with irregular nuclear borders. In urothelial cancer, urine cytology shows abnormal cells with a very high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, dark coarse chromatin, and irregular borders; prominent nucleoli are occasionally seen in large, often single cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Bladder cancer is not associated with tattoos.

D) INCORRECT:

Bladder cancer is not associated with heavy alcohol use.

E) INCORRECT:

Although sexual history can be useful to evaluate risks for cancers related to HIV, hepatitis C virus, and human papillomavirus, bladder cancer is not clearly associated with sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-week history of painless hematuria. CT scan of the urinary tract reveals areas of bladder wall thickening. Cystoscopy identifies several sessile masses with central necrosis arising from the bladder wall. Biopsy of the bladder masses shows moderately differentiated urothelial cells with abundant mitotic figures and nuclear atypia. Which one of the following exposures is this patient most likely to have a history of?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vinyl chloride is a chemical that especially plumbers are exposed to when working with polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes. Although vinyl chloride is carcinogenic, it has primarily been linked to liver angiosarcoma and not urothelial cancer. It also increases the risk of brain cancer, lung cancer, leukemia, and lymphoma.

B) CORRECT:

A strong risk factor for urothelial cancer is prolonged exposure to aromatic amines like benzidine. These chemicals are especially associated with the rubber production, oil refining, and dye-making industries. Other risk factors for urothelial cancer include nicotine abuse, arsenic exposure, and cyclophosphamide use.

Key learning point: Aromatic amine exposure, especially in dye, rubber, and oil industries, is a major risk factor for urothelial (bladder) carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Exposure to ionizing radiation is associated with certain occupations, previous cancer treatments, and living environments (e.g., near nuclear power plants). It has been found to be associated with later development of papillary thyroid cancer, not bladder cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Aflatoxins are toxins produced by Aspergillus flavus, which is a fungus that can grow on improperly stored nuts and rice. Although aflatoxins are carcinogenic, they have been primarily linked to hepatocellular carcinoma and not urothelial cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitrosamines are compounds formed from nitrites and amines and are found in certain foods like smoked meats. They have been found to be carcinogenic, but are most closely associated with the development of gastric cancer.
questions.hint: A history of painless hematuria, combined with the cystoscopic finding of bladder masses composed of atypical urothelial cells, is consistent with urothelial carcinoma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of painless gross hematuria. He does not have dysuria, urinary frequency or urgency, or flank pain. He takes no medications and has no known medical conditions. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows no masses or lymphadenopathy. Urinalysis confirms gross hematuria with numerous RBCs/HPF, no leukocytes, and no bacteria. Urine culture is negative. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with primary care follow-up in 2 weeks
Urology consult for renal ultrasound with post-void residual

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While cystoscopy is essential for complete evaluation of gross hematuria, imaging should be performed first because instrumentation can cause inflammation that makes subsequent radiological interpretation challenging.

B) INCORRECT:

Based on the patient's age, smoking history, and persistent gross hematuria, urgent evaluation for urinary tract malignancy is required. Delaying evaluation in a high-risk patient with gross hematuria is inappropriate and could lead to delayed diagnosis of potentially curable cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

While renal ultrasound can detect bladder and renal masses, it has significantly lower sensitivity for detecting carcinomas of the renal pelvis and ureters compared to first-line imaging.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- CT urography is the preferred initial imaging study for evaluating gross hematuria in patients at risk for urinary tract malignancy. This patient's age (> 60 years) and significant smoking history place him at high risk for urothelial carcinoma. CT urography allows comprehensive evaluation of the entire urinary tract, including the renal pelvis, ureters, and bladder, in a single study.

E) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology is used as an adjunct study in the evaluation of gross hematuria but is not the primary initial diagnostic step. It has limited sensitivity for low-grade tumors and should not delay appropriate imaging in a high-risk patient with gross hematuria.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a two-month history of painless, intermittent gross hematuria. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He denies dysuria or flank pain. Vital signs are stable, and the physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis confirms numerous red blood cells without casts or signs of infection. A cystoscopy is planned. Further history regarding which of the following is most likely to identify an additional risk factor for this patient's suspected condition?

choices.text: Employment in the rubber manufacturing industry
Past occupation as a coal miner

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vinyl chloride is a known human carcinogen used in the production of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) plastics. Chronic occupational exposure is strongly linked to a rare type of liver cancer known as hepatic angiosarcoma. It is not associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation of painless gross hematuria is highly concerning for bladder cancer, most commonly urothelial carcinoma. While smoking is the most significant risk factor, occupational exposures account for a substantial number of cases. Employment in the rubber, dye, textile, and leather industries involves exposure to aromatic amines (e.g., benzidine, 2-naphthylamine), which are potent carcinogens. These chemicals are metabolized by the liver and excreted in the urine, where they have prolonged contact with the urothelium, leading to DNA damage and malignant transformation. There is often a long latency period, sometimes decades, between exposure and the development of cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Sandblasting involves exposure to crystalline silica dust, which can cause silicosis, a fibrotic lung disease. This exposure also increases the risk of developing lung cancer and tuberculosis. However, silica exposure is not an established risk factor for the development of bladder cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Asbestos is a well-known carcinogen, but its exposure is primarily associated with pulmonary diseases. It is the leading cause of malignant mesothelioma and significantly increases the risk of bronchogenic carcinoma, particularly in smokers. It is not considered a primary risk factor for developing bladder cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

A history of coal mining is associated with coal workers' pneumoconiosis, a restrictive lung disease. While it may also be associated with an increased risk for other conditions like chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and lung cancer, it is not a recognized risk factor for bladder cancer.
questions.hint: The patient's painless gross hematuria and smoking history strongly suggest bladder cancer. Occupations that involve exposure to aromatic amines affect the urinary tract.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the clinic with a two-week history of painless, gross hematuria. His medical history is notable for hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis shows numerous red blood cells. A subsequent cystoscopy reveals a 2-cm papillary tumor on the lateral bladder wall. Biopsy results confirm high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma without invasion into the muscularis propria. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Transurethral resection of the tumor alone
Transurethral resection followed by adjuvant therapy
Systemic chemotherapy with a cisplatin-based regimen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transurethral resection of the bladder tumor (TURBT) is the essential first step in managing all non-muscle invasive bladder cancers. However, for a high-grade tumor like this patient's, TURBT alone is insufficient due to the very high likelihood of tumor recurrence and progression to a more advanced, muscle-invasive stage. Adjuvant therapy is required to mitigate this risk.

B) CORRECT:

The standard of care for this patient with high-risk non-muscle invasive bladder cancer is a two-step approach. First, a transurethral resection of the bladder tumor is performed to remove all visible tumors and provide accurate staging. Second, because of the high risk of recurrence and progression to muscle-invasive disease, adjuvant intravesical therapy is initiated. Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG), a live attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis, is the agent of choice. It works by inducing a local, T-cell mediated immune and inflammatory response that eradicates residual cancer cells. For high-risk non-muscle invasive bladder cancer, BCG has been shown to be superior to intravesical chemotherapy in reducing the risk of disease progression.

C) INCORRECT:

Radical cystectomy is a major surgical procedure that provides definitive treatment for bladder cancer, but it is not the appropriate initial therapy for non-muscle invasive disease. This approach is reserved for patients with muscle-invasive bladder cancer (stage T2 or higher) or for those with high-risk non-muscle invasive cancer that is refractory to or recurs after other management approaches.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravesical chemotherapy, such as with mitomycin C, is a valid treatment option for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer. It is most commonly used for low or intermediate-risk tumors to reduce the risk of recurrence. However, for high-risk disease, as indicated by the high-grade pathology in this patient, a more effective management approach is warranted.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic chemotherapy is a mainstay of treatment for advanced urothelial carcinoma, specifically for metastatic disease or as a component of treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer (often given before or after radical cystectomy). It is not indicated for localized, non-muscle invasive bladder cancer, as the disease is confined to the bladder lining.
questions.hint: The biopsy confirms non-muscle invasive bladder cancer, but the high-grade histology significantly increases the risk of recurrence and progression.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents for follow-up after undergoing a cystoscopy with transurethral resection for painless gross hematuria. The final pathology report confirms high-grade urothelial carcinoma invading the muscularis propria. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows bladder wall thickening but no evidence of lymph node involvement or distant metastatic disease. The patient has a good performance status and no significant comorbidities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: External beam radiation therapy with concurrent chemotherapy
Neoadjuvant cisplatin-based chemotherapy followed by radical cystectomy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radical cystectomy is the definitive surgical procedure for muscle-invasive bladder cancer. However, performing surgery as a single modality is now considered suboptimal. Level I evidence from multiple clinical trials has shown a significant overall survival benefit with an alternative management approach.

B) INCORRECT:

This approach, known as trimodality therapy, is a bladder-preserving option for muscle-invasive bladder cancer. However, for a fit candidate like this patient, an alternative management approach is generally considered the gold standard with the most robust long-term data for oncologic control.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has localized muscle-invasive bladder cancer, specifically stage T2N0M0. The standard of care for fit patients is a multimodal approach aimed at cure. Neoadjuvant cisplatin-based chemotherapy is administered before surgery to treat potential micrometastatic disease and downstage the primary tumor, which has been shown to improve overall survival compared to surgery alone. Following chemotherapy, a radical cystectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection is performed for definitive local control. This patient's good performance status and lack of comorbidities make him an ideal candidate for this aggressive, curative-intent therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Pembrolizumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor used in urothelial carcinoma, but not typically in this specific clinical scenario. It is approved as an adjuvant therapy after cystectomy for patients at high risk of recurrence or for patients with metastatic disease. Level I evidence from multiple clinical trials has shown a significant overall survival benefit with an alternative management approach.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravesical Bacillus Calmette-Guérin is a form of immunotherapy delivered directly into the bladder. While it is the standard of care for high-risk non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer (e.g., carcinoma in situ, high-grade T1 tumors), it is not an effective treatment once the cancer has invaded the muscularis propria. The risk of systemic progression and metastasis is too high to be managed with local therapy alone.
questions.hint: The pathology finding of invasion into the muscularis propria defines this as muscle-invasive bladder cancer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of lower back pain. He has had several episodes of painless hematuria over the past 2 months. Physical examination shows localized tenderness over the lumbar spine. A CT scan shows multiple osteolytic lesions in the body of the lumbar vertebrae. Cystoscopy shows a 4-cm mass in the right lateral wall of the bladder. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic alcohol consumption is associated with an increased risk of hepatic and esophageal carcinomas as well as chronic pancreatitis, which may increase the risk of pancreatic carcinomas. Although chronic pancreatitis may also manifest with chronic back pain, this patient's back complaints and CT findings are more consistent with metastatic lesions. Alcohol consumption is not known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma.

B) CORRECT:

Smoking is the most important risk factor for the development of both the transitional cell type of carcinomas of the bladder and the less common squamous cell type. Other risk factors for urothelial cancer include long-term occupational exposure to benzidine and aniline dyes as well as previous cyclophosphamide treatment. Most urothelial cancers occur in males > 65 years, and affected individuals classically present with painless gross hematuria. This patient's osteolytic lesions and lower back pain indicate advanced metastatic disease.

When in doubt, the most commonly tested risk factor on exam questions is cigarette smoking, and smoking cessation is the best way to improve overall health!

C) INCORRECT:

Infection with Clonorchis sinensis, or Chinese liver fluke, is a significant risk factor for development of cholangiocarcinoma. Patients with cholangiocarcinomas typically present with abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss, and pale stools, unlike this patient with primarily urinary complaints. Clonorchis infection does not increase the risk for bladder carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder is the most common type of bladder cancer in regions with a high prevalence of Schistosoma haematobium infection, such as the Middle East and Sub-Saharan Africa. Biopsy of a squamous cell carcinoma would classically show epithelial infiltrates, keratin pearls, and intercellular bridges. While this patient presents with painless hematuria and a bladder mass on cystoscopy, his biopsy findings demonstrate features consistent with transitional cell carcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma. Additional risk factors for development of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder include chronic cystitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Long-term exposure to vinyl chloride is associated with an increased risk of hepatic angiosarcoma, lymphoma, glioblastoma, and lung carcinoma. However, there is no known association between vinyl chloride exposure and risk of developing bladder cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

Nitrosamine is a chemical most commonly found in cured, smoked, and processed foods. High consumption of this substance has been associated with an increased risk of gastric carcinoma, but not with a higher risk of bladder cancer.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows a fibrovascular core surrounded by a thickened, dysplastic urothelium with loss of polarity. These features are consistent with transitional cell urothelial carcinoma.
